questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: Based on the location of the intraretinal fluid, which imaging modality and location would be most beneficial?

answers.explanation:
The fluid is primarily found in the nasal macula, respecting the fovea, transversing towards the optic nerve which is nasal to the fovea. This is the peripapillary region. Therefore, asking the technician to localize the 5-line raster over the peripapillary area would be crucial to provide further information of the disease process and to rule out optic nerve related disease processes.

References: 

Hong SW, Ahn MD, Kang SH, Im SK. Analysis of peripapillary retinal nerve fiber distribution in normal young adults. Glaucoma 2010;51:3515-3523.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
OCT 5-line rasters of the peripapillary areas OU were completed and shown below:

![](/content/media/retina45_6.webp)

![](/content/media/retina45_7.webp)

Based on the findings on OCT macula and peripapillary regions, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Peripapillary pachychoroid syndrome (PPS) is a variant of the pachychoroid disease spectrum which presents with localized intra-retinal and/or subretinal fluid primarily in the peripapillary region. These patients typically have thicker nasal macular choroids with enlarged Haller’s vessels, in keeping with pachychoroid disease. The landmark study introducing PPS in 2018 also demonstrated associations to discs at risk, choroidal folds, hyperopes, and peripapillary pigmentary mottling without focal leakage on fundus autofluorescence. This disease is not related to the pathophysiology of diabetic macular edema.

References:

1. Phasukkijwatana N, Freund KB, Dolz-Marco R, et al. Peripapillary pachychoroid syndrome. Retina 2019;38(9):1652-1667.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What treatment would be indicated for this patient?

answers.explanation:
A study by Xu et al. in 2020 investigated the treatment outcomes of patients with PPS managed with laser, anti-VEGF injections or observation. This study concluded that there was no significant difference in visual outcomes for patients managed conservatively versus those managed medically. Therefore, saving patients from un-necessary treatment by effectively diagnosing PPS, rather than DME, is crucial.

References:

1. Xu D, Garg E, Sakurada Y. Long-term visual and anatomic outcomes of patients with peripapillary pachychoroid syndrome. Br J Ophthalmol 2020;0:1-6.

title: Case 45
description: 80M presenting with persistent intraretinal fluid bilaterally
patientPresentation:
An 80-year-old male was referred to a tertiary retina clinic for assessment of bilateral persistent intraretinal fluid. Patient failed topical treatment for CME and repeated intravitreal anti-VEGF. Past medical history includes T2DM, hypertension, dyslipidemia and coronary artery disease.

Vision was 20/40 OD and 20/30 OS with no RAPD and IOP within normal limits. Slit lamp examination was unremarkable. Dilated fundus examination demonstrated stable intraretinal fluid temporal to the optic disc respecting the macula OU, as well as scattered hard exudates at the macula.
